Image Description:
Figure 4-1 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth provides a detailed visual representation of the developmental stages of bees, focusing on the transitions from egg to larva. The figure is divided into several panels, each illustrating a different stage in the early life of a bee. Panel 4-1a depicts the elongate and gently curved eggs, which are whitish and have a soft, membranous chorion. These eggs are typically laid on or within the food mass intended for larval consumption. This setup is crucial for the initial nourishment of the larvae upon hatching.

Panels 4-1b through 4-1d sequentially illustrate the progression of the larval stage, showing the transformation from newly hatched larvae to more developed forms. These larvae are depicted as soft, whitish, legless grubs. The figure highlights how these larvae typically lie on the upper surface of the food mass, consuming the food below and in front of them. This feeding strategy supports their rapid growth and multiple moltings, which are essential processes in their development towards pupation.

Overall, Fig. 4-1 effectively encapsulates the critical early developmental stages of bees, emphasizing the morphological changes and feeding behaviors that are pivotal for their growth and survival. This figure serves as a valuable educational tool for understanding the complex life cycle of bees, particularly the dynamics of their growth from egg to larva.

The axilla is depicted as rounded, contrasting with more angular forms found in other genera. These features are critical for distinguishing C. gracillima from closely related species within the Megachilini tribe, aiding in accurate classification and study of bee biodiversity. This visual representation serves as an essential reference for entomologists and researchers focusing on bee taxonomy and morphology.

The figure is divided into parts labeled 20-5b and 20-5c, each highlighting different anatomical details relevant to their taxonomy and identification.

In part 20-5b, the figure illustrates the episternal groove extending below the scrobal groove, though it is noted to be frequently shallow. This feature is significant as it helps in distinguishing members of the Rophitinae from other bee families. The positioning of the antennae, which arise below the middle of the face, is also clearly depicted, providing a visual reference for this diagnostic characteristic.

Part 20-5c of the figure shifts focus to the episternal groove as it is commonly found in the Family Apidae, where it extends down to or curves into and joins the scrobal groove. This specific anatomical trait is crucial for differentiating between subfamilies within the Apidae.

Overall, Figure 20-5 serves as a comparative anatomical reference that aids in the identification and classification of female bees within the families Rophitinae and Apidae, emphasizing the variations in the episternal groove across different groups.

This detailed depiction aids in understanding the unique structural adaptations within the Oxaeinae, contributing to their identification and classification within the broader bee taxonomy.

Image Description:
Figure 33-2 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth illustrates the anatomical variations in the labrum and subantennal areas across different bee families, specifically highlighting the Megachilidae, Apidae, Andrenidae, and Halictidae families. Each panel (a through d) in the figure provides a detailed view of these structures, which are crucial for taxonomic differentiation among these families.

Panel 33-2a focuses on the Megachilidae family, showing a labrum with enlarged basolateral angles and a broad base forming a wide articulation with the clypeus, characteristic of this family. The labrum is depicted as widest at its base, which is a distinctive feature for identification.

Panel 33-2b represents the Apidae family, where the labrum has less developed basolateral angles and a narrower articulation with the clypeus compared to Megachilidae. This panel illustrates a labrum that is usually broader than long, aiding in distinguishing members of this family.

Panel 33-2c details the Andrenidae family, specifically focusing on the subantennal area defined by two sutures below each antennal socket. This feature, along with the presence of a facial fovea in females and some males, is key for recognizing this family.

Lastly, panel 33-2d shows the Halictidae family, where the labrum has little to no development of basolateral angles and features a single subantennal suture below each antennal socket, which helps differentiate this family from others.

This figure effectively encapsulates critical morphological features used in the taxonomic classification of these bee families, providing a clear visual reference for comparative studies.

Image Description: Figure 81-2 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth illustrates key anatomical features of male bees of the genus Osmia from the tribe Osmiini in the Eastern Hemisphere. This figure is particularly focused on the characteristics of the parapsidal lines and the segmentation of the abdomen, specifically segments S2, S3, and S4. The parapsidal lines are depicted as punctiform or very short-linear, typically less than one-fifth the length of the tegula, as shown in subfigure 81-2a. Segment S3 is noted for being commonly emarginate with a fringe in the emargination, largely or wholly covered by an enlarged S2, while S4 is neither emarginate nor fringed. These features are crucial for distinguishing the species within this genus and understanding their morphological adaptations. The figure serves as a visual reference for these specific anatomical details, aiding in the identification and classification of Osmia species within this geographical and taxonomic scope.

Image Description: Figure 81-3 from "Bees of the World" by Daniel C. Danforth illustrates the anatomical features of the propodeum in the genus Heriades of the tribe Osmiini. This figure is pivotal for understanding the distinct morphology that characterizes these bees, particularly in the Western Hemisphere. The illustration clearly delineates the narrow horizontal basal zone of the propodeum, which is sharply separated from the declivous posterior surface by a prominent carina. Additionally, it shows the division of this area into a series of large pits by multiple carinae, a key identification feature. The anterior surface of T1 (the first segment of the thorax) is also depicted as broadly concave and bounded by a strong carina, highlighting another significant morphological trait. The absence or weakness of lines that would normally delimit the propodeal triangle in other genera is noted, underscoring the unique structural adaptations in Heriades. This figure serves as an essential visual aid for entomologists and taxonomists studying the morphology and classification of bee species within this specific tribe.

Danforth illustrates the morphological differences in the hind tibial structures of various subgenera of the bee genus Stelis, specifically focusing on those found in the Eastern Hemisphere. This figure is divided into two parts: 82-13a and 82-13b, each depicting the hind tibial apex characteristics that distinguish between the subgenera Heterostelis and S. (Stelis s. str.), respectively.

In Fig. 82-13a, the hind tibial apex of the subgenus Heterostelis is shown with a single spine or angle, which is largely obscured by surrounding hairs. This spine is positioned near the posterior apical angle of the tibia, with the apex of the tibia presenting a convex margin. This configuration is typical for subgenera where the scutellum is laterally carinate and the head and thorax exhibit light markings.

Conversely, Fig. 82-13b details the hind tibial apex of the subgenus S. (Stelis s. str.), where there are two distinct spines or angles. One of these spines is located near the outer middle of the apical tibial margin. This part of the tibia is sparsely hairy, making the structural details more visible compared to those in subgenus Heterostelis. This feature is indicative of subgenera with a non-carinate scutellum and no light markings on the head and thorax.

This figure serves as a crucial visual aid for differentiating these subgenera based on detailed anatomical features of the hind tibia, which are significant for taxonomic and identification purposes in entomological studies.

Panels 84-6f and 84-6g focus on the T6 segment in males, with 84-6f displaying a lateral basal tooth and 84-6g lacking both a lateral tooth and long erect hairs, which are critical for distinguishing between subgenera within the Eastern Hemisphere.

This figure serves as a crucial visual aid for researchers and enthusiasts in identifying and understanding the morphological differences within the Coelioxys genus, particularly in the context of female and male differentiation across geographical regions such as Africa, the oriental, and Australia.
